question.title: Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Donald Trump Jr. becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now, Donald Trump Sr. is the frontrunner for the 2024 Republican nomination, with other established politicians like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley also in the race. Donald Trump Jr. has not announced any intention to run. 2. Lack of political experience: Donald Trump Jr. has never held elected office, which is typically a prerequisite for a major party's presidential nominee. While his father succeeded without prior political experience, this is extremely rare. 3. Family dynasty concerns: The Republican Party may be hesitant to nominate another Trump family member so soon after Donald Trump Sr.'s presidency, as it could be seen as promoting a political dynasty. 4. Name recognition: While Donald Trump Jr. does have high name recognition due to his father's presidency and his own media presence, this alone is not sufficient for securing a nomination. 5. Base support: He does have a following among his father's base, but it's unclear if this would translate to broader Republican support necessary for a nomination. 6. Timing: The question was created in 2021, and as of 2023, Donald Trump Jr. has not shown any serious indications of running for the presidency in 2024. 7. Competition: There are several other high-profile Republicans who are either running or considered likely to run, making the field competitive even without Donald Trump Jr.'s participation. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Donald Trump Jr. will be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While not impossible, it would require a dramatic and unexpected shift in the current political landscape.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (1) If Joe Biden drops out, will a reliable media outlet cover the story at least 6 hours in advance? (2) Will Donald Trump Jr. be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(1) This resolves as YES if a major and reliable media outlet like Associated Press News, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, or Washington Post covers Joe Biden's dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before his official announcement. The question is N/A if he does not drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention. 

(2) This resolves as YES if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, regardless of who is nominated on the election day itself.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This question requires both conditions to be met for a YES resolution, so we need to consider the probability of each event occurring and then multiply them. 1. Joe Biden dropping out and media coverage: The likelihood of Joe Biden dropping out before the Democratic National Convention is quite low. He is the incumbent president and has consistently expressed his intention to run for re-election. Even if he were to drop out, the probability of a major media outlet covering it at least 6 hours in advance is high, as such news would be significant and likely to leak. However, the overall probability of this condition being met is still low due to the unlikelihood of Biden dropping out. 2. Donald Trump Jr. being the Republican nominee: This is extremely unlikely. While Donald Trump Jr. is a prominent figure in Republican politics, he has not indicated any intention to run for president in 2024. His father, Donald Trump, is currently the frontrunner for the Republican nomination. Other prominent Republicans like Ron DeSantis and Nikki Haley are also in the race. For Donald Trump Jr. to become the nominee, it would require a series of highly improbable events, such as all current candidates dropping out or a major shift in Republican voter preferences. Given that both of these unlikely events need to occur for a YES resolution, the overall probability is very low. The probability of the first event (Biden dropping out with advance media coverage) might be around 0.05, and the probability of the second event (Donald Trump Jr. becoming the nominee) might be even lower, around 0.01. Multiplying these probabilities gives us an extremely low overall probability.

question.title: Will either of the following occur: (a) If Joe Biden drops out, a reliable media outlet covers the story at least 6 hours in advance (b) Donald Trump Jr. is the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
(a) If Joe Biden drops out, this question resolves YES if a big and reliable media outlet like Associated Press News, CNN, New York Times, Wall Street Journal, Fox News, Reuters, or Washington Post covers the dropout with an unofficial confirmation at least 6 hours before President Joe Biden officially announces his dropout via letter, speech, etc. Local news, conspiracy websites, or comments by individual users on Manifold will not be sufficient. This market will be resolved as N/A if President Joe Biden does not drop out before the end of the National Democratic Convention.

(b) This question resolves YES if Donald Trump Jr. is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as NO. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future. It is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the Republican National Convention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving YES, we need to consider both parts (a) and (b) separately, as either one occurring would lead to a YES resolution. (a) Joe Biden dropping out: Currently, there is no strong indication that Joe Biden intends to drop out of the 2024 presidential race. He has announced his re-election campaign and seems committed to running. However, there are concerns about his age and health that could potentially lead to a dropout, albeit with a low probability. If he were to drop out, it's highly likely that major media outlets would cover the story well in advance of an official announcement, given the significance of such an event. Probability for (a): Approximately 5-10%. (b) Donald Trump Jr. as the Republican nominee: This scenario is extremely unlikely. While Donald Trump Jr. is a prominent figure in Republican circles, he has not indicated any intention to run for president in 2024. His father, Donald Trump, is currently the frontrunner for the Republican nomination. Other candidates like Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and Tim Scott are also in the race. For Donald Trump Jr. to become the nominee, all of these candidates would need to drop out or lose significant support, and Trump Jr. would need to enter the race and gain overwhelming support quickly. Probability for (b): Less than 1%. Combining probabilities: Since either (a) or (b) occurring would resolve the question as YES, we need to consider the probability of at least one of these events happening. Given that these events are largely independent, we can use the formula: P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B). Using the higher end of our estimate for (a) and a generous estimate for (b): P(YES) = 0.10 + 0.01 - (0.10 * 0.01) = 0.109 or approximately 11%. This calculation suggests that there's about an 11% chance of either event occurring, leading to a YES resolution.

question.title: Will Joe Biden announce before July 15, 2024 that he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, Joe Biden or his campaign makes a definitive, public, official announcement to the effect that Joe Biden will not seek and will not accept the nomination of his party for another term as President of the United States in the 2024 cycle.

To qualify for a **Yes** resolution, the statement must be unambiguous and conclusive: it should leave no room for the possibility that Biden would accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President of the United States in the 2024 election cycle.

If such a definitive statement is not made prior to 00:00 Eastern on July 15, 2024, this question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden announcing he will not accept the Democratic Party's nomination for President before July 15, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbency advantage: Historically, incumbent presidents rarely decline to run for a second term unless facing significant health issues or extremely low approval ratings. Biden is the incumbent, which typically favors running for re-election. 2. Age and health concerns: Biden is currently 81 years old and would be 86 at the end of a second term. There have been ongoing discussions about his age and fitness for office, which could potentially influence his decision. 3. Current political climate: As of now, Biden is the presumptive Democratic nominee and has been campaigning for re-election. He has not shown any signs of stepping down or declining the nomination. 4. Time frame: The question's resolution date is relatively close to the Democratic National Convention, which is typically held in August. It's unlikely for a sitting president to withdraw so close to the convention without extenuating circumstances. 5. Lack of strong alternative candidates: The Democratic Party hasn't been grooming any clear alternatives to Biden, which suggests they are committed to his candidacy. 6. Biden's public statements: He has repeatedly stated his intention to run for re-election and has not indicated any plans to step down. 7. Political stability: Withdrawing from the race at this stage could potentially destabilize the Democratic Party's election strategy and might be seen as detrimental to the party's chances in the general election. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would announce he will not accept the nomination before July 15, 2024. While age and health concerns are real factors, they don't appear to be severe enough at this time to force such a drastic decision. The political costs of withdrawing so close to the election would be significant, and there's no clear indication that Biden or his team are considering this option. However, we must acknowledge that unexpected events could occur, such as a sudden health crisis or a major political scandal, which could change the situation rapidly. These low-probability events prevent us from assigning a probability of exactly 0.

question.title: Will Russia have control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if, when accessed by Metaculus on June 1, 2024, the [Institute for the Study of War (ISW) map](https://storymaps.arcgis.com/stories/36a7f6a6f5a9448496de641cf64bd375) shows the coordinates 48°35'13.7"N 37°50'02.1"E as under any of the following categories:



- Assessed Russian Advance in Ukraine

- Assessed Russian Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Assessed Russian Control

- Claimed Russian Territory in Ukraine

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Russian control of the location



The question will resolve as **No** if the location is not assessed to be in any of the categories indicating Russian control, which includes but is not limited to:



- Reported Ukrainian Territorial Gains in the Past 24 Hours

- Claimed Ukrainian Counteroffensives

- Reported Ukrainian Partisan Warfare

- Any other categories created by ISW that indicate Ukrainian control of the location or a lack of Russian control of the location

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Russia having control of Chasiv Yar on June 1, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current situation: As of April 2024, Chasiv Yar is still under Ukrainian control, but it's close to the front lines and has been a target of Russian forces. 2. Strategic importance: Chasiv Yar is considered strategically important due to its location west of Bakhmut, which Russia captured in May 2023. Taking Chasiv Yar would allow Russia to push further into Donetsk Oblast. 3. Time frame: The question asks about the situation approximately 13 months from now, which is a significant amount of time in terms of military operations. 4. Recent Russian offensive: Russia has been conducting a renewed offensive in eastern Ukraine, making slow but steady progress in some areas. 5. Ukrainian defenses: Ukraine has been fortifying its positions and receiving continued Western support, which could help them maintain control of key areas. 6. Historical context: Russia's advance in the Donbas region has been slow but persistent over the past year, suggesting they might continue to make gradual progress. 7. Uncertainty factors: The course of the war could be influenced by various factors such as changes in international support, internal political developments in both countries, or potential peace negotiations. Given these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that Russia could capture Chasiv Yar by June 1, 2024, but it's far from certain. The extended timeframe gives Russia more opportunity to advance, but also allows Ukraine time to reinforce its defenses. The slow pace of Russian gains suggests they might reach Chasiv Yar, but holding it by the specified date is less certain.

question.body: For Inflection, this question resolves as **YES** if, by June 30, 2024, they publish a *public* report with the results from an *external* party red-teaming the safety of one of their AI models.

question.title: Will OpenAI's ChatGPT be generally available in the European Union on June 30, 2024?
question.body:
The question resolves as **YES** if [ChatGPT](chat.openai.com) is generally available in the EU on June 30, 2024, and **NO** otherwise.

"Generally available" here means that the default state for people in the EU is that they can access it without a VPN (possibly requiring paying for it.) If unavailable in certain EU countries (as was the case in Italy in early 2023), or unavailable to (for example) minors, this will still resolve positively, assuming at least >50% of the population can use it.

"ChatGPT" here refers to the general web interface (not the API) for interacting with GPT models. Still resolves positively if the name or website has changed, as long as OpenAI's service is substantially the same (entering queries to systems based on Large Language Models).

question.title: Will Malta qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if Malta participates in a Semi-final and is then officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If they do not qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess Malta's chances of qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Malta has participated in Eurovision since 1971 and has qualified for the Grand Final in 6 out of the last 10 contests (2013-2023, excluding 2020 which was cancelled). This shows a relatively good track record. 2. Recent performance: In 2023, Malta failed to qualify for the Grand Final, finishing 12th in their semi-final. This might indicate a slight downturn in their competitive edge. 3. Semi-final allocation: The semi-final allocation for 2024 hasn't been determined yet, which could impact Malta's chances depending on the competition in their group. 4. Song and artist selection: As of now, Malta hasn't announced their entry for 2024. The quality of the song and the performer will play a crucial role in their chances of qualification. 5. Voting patterns: Malta often receives support from countries like Italy and Australia due to diaspora voting, which can help in qualification. 6. Competition level: The overall quality of entries in 2024 is unknown, which could affect Malta's relative standing. 7. Staging and performance: Malta's staging has been hit-or-miss in recent years, which can significantly impact voting results. 8. Jury vs. public vote: Malta has historically performed better with juries than with the public vote. The balance between these two could affect their qualification chances. Given these factors, Malta has a fair chance of qualifying, but it's not a certainty. Their historical performance suggests they're more likely than not to qualify, but recent results and unknown factors for 2024 add uncertainty.

question.title: Will Serbia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Serbia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. This gives them an 84.6% qualification rate. 2. Recent performance: In the last five years (2019, 2021-2023), Serbia has qualified for the Grand Final every time. This shows consistent recent success. 3. Competition format: Typically, 10 out of 16-18 countries qualify from each semi-final, giving each country a base probability of about 55-62% to qualify. 6. Time until the event: As the question is being asked almost a year before Eurovision 2024, there's still uncertainty about the song Serbia will send and the overall competition level. 7. Potential changes: While unlikely, there's always a small chance of rule changes or exceptional circumstances that could affect qualification chances. Given Serbia's strong historical performance, consistent recent qualifications, and favorable voting patterns, the chances of them qualifying are significantly higher than the base probability. However, we must account for the uncertainty of their future entry and potential strong competition.

question.title: Will either Malta or Serbia qualify for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if either of the following occurs: (a) Malta participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. (b) Serbia participates in a Semi-final and is officially announced by the European Broadcasting Union (EBU) as having qualified for the Eurovision 2024 Grand Final. If neither Malta nor Serbia qualify, the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of either Malta or Serbia qualifying for the Grand Final in Eurovision 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: Malta has qualified for the Grand Final 7 times out of the last 10 contests they participated in. Serbia has a stronger track record, qualifying 9 times out of the last 10 contests. 2. Recent performance: Malta failed to qualify in 2022 and 2023, showing a downward trend. Serbia has consistently qualified in recent years, including 2022 and 2023. 3. Eurovision voting patterns: Both countries have established voting blocs that can help them. Serbia benefits from Balkan bloc voting, while Malta often receives support from other small nations. 4. Quality of entries: While we don't know the specific entries for 2024 yet, both countries have historically sent competitive entries. 5. Semi-final allocation: The distribution of countries in each semi-final can significantly impact qualification chances. This information is not available yet for 2024. 6. Number of qualifiers: Typically, 10 countries qualify from each semi-final, giving a base probability of about 50% for any given country to qualify. 7. Combined chances: With two countries in question, the chances of at least one qualifying are higher than for a single country. Given Serbia's strong track record and consistent recent performances, they have a good chance of qualifying, probably around 70-75%. Malta's chances are lower due to recent failures, but still significant, perhaps around 40-45%. When we combine these probabilities, considering that we only need one of them to qualify, the overall probability is higher than either individual chance. Using the complement rule of probability (1 - probability of both failing), we get: 1 - (0.3 * 0.6) = 1 - 0.18 = 0.82. This calculation assumes independence, which isn't entirely accurate due to potential voting patterns, but it gives us a reasonable estimate.

question.title: Will the domestic box office opening of "Deadpool & Wolverine" be higher than that of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" combined?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the domestic box office opening for the **Deadpool & Wolverine** reported by Boxofficemojo on the [movie's page](https://www.boxofficemojo.com/title/tt6263850/?ref_=bo_se_r_1) is higher than $185,548,391 which is the sum of the box openings for **Deadpool** (2016) and **The Wolverine** (2013): $132,434,639 + $53,113,752.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of 'Deadpool & Wolverine' surpassing the combined opening box office of 'Deadpool' and 'The Wolverine,' we need to consider several factors: 1. Franchise popularity: Both Deadpool and Wolverine are extremely popular characters in the Marvel universe, with dedicated fan bases. 2. Previous performance: 'Deadpool' had an exceptional opening of $132,434,639, while 'The Wolverine' opened at $53,113,752. The combined target to beat is $185,548,391. 3. Synergy effect: Combining these two popular characters in one film is likely to create significant buzz and attract fans of both franchises. 4. Marvel Cinematic Universe (MCU) integration: This film is expected to integrate these characters into the MCU, which could draw additional interest from the broader Marvel fanbase. 5. Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman: The star power and chemistry between these actors, known from previous films, will likely be a major draw. 6. Marketing and anticipation: Given the popularity of both characters, the marketing campaign is likely to be extensive, building significant anticipation. 7. Post-pandemic box office recovery: By 2024, the movie industry should have largely recovered from pandemic-related setbacks, potentially leading to higher attendance. 8. Inflation: Ticket prices in 2024 will likely be higher than in 2013 and 2016, making it easier to achieve higher box office numbers. 9. Opening weekend trends: Blockbuster movies, especially in the superhero genre, tend to have increasingly front-loaded opening weekends. Given these factors, it seems highly likely that 'Deadpool & Wolverine' will surpass the combined opening weekend box office of its predecessors. The combination of two popular characters, star power, MCU integration, and the general trend of increasing opening weekend numbers for major franchises all point towards a strong performance. However, there's always some uncertainty in box office predictions, and factors like competition from other films, critical reception, or unexpected events could impact the results.

"Split" - B+

"Glass" - B

"Old" - C+

"Knock at the Cabin" - C

You can search the CinemaScore website for more examples.

This trend suggests that audience reception of his recent works has been declining. 2. Shyamalan's reputation: He's known for his twist endings and unique storytelling style. While this has garnered him a dedicated fanbase, it has also led to mixed receptions for many of his films. 3. Genre and expectations: "Trap" is likely to be a thriller or horror film, given Shyamalan's typical style. These genres often receive lower CinemaScores due to their divisive nature. 4. Trailer reception: The question mentions a "great trailer." A well-received trailer can build positive expectations, potentially leading to a better initial audience response. 5. Shyamalan's ability to surprise: He has shown the ability to bounce back with critically and commercially successful films after periods of less well-received work (e.g., "Split" after a series of poorly received films). 6. Time since last film: With "Knock at the Cabin" releasing in 2023, Shyamalan has had some time to refine his approach based on recent feedback. Given these factors, I believe "Trap" has a chance of receiving a B CinemaScore or higher, but it's not highly likely. The recent downward trend in his CinemaScores is concerning, with his last two films receiving below a B. However, the positive trailer reception and Shyamalan's potential for comeback films provide some hope for improvement.

metadata.chain_of_thought:
To answer this question, we need to consider both parts separately and then combine their probabilities.

1. "Deadpool & Wolverine" box office opening:
The combined opening of "Deadpool" and "The Wolverine" was $185,548,391. "Deadpool & Wolverine" needs to surpass this to fulfill part (a) of the question. 

Factors in favor:

Factors against:

- Post-pandemic box office performance has been somewhat unpredictable.

Given these factors, I'd estimate there's about a 70% chance of "Deadpool & Wolverine" surpassing the combined opening of its predecessors.

2. "Trap" CinemaScore:
M. Night Shyamalan's films have received varying CinemaScores, ranging from B+ to C. 

Factors to consider:
- Shyamalan's recent films have generally received lower CinemaScores (C+ for "Old", C for "Knock at the Cabin").
- However, he has achieved B and B+ scores in the past with films like "Split" and "Glass".
- The specific plot and marketing of "Trap" are unknown at this time, which could significantly impact audience reception.

Given Shyamalan's recent trend and the unpredictability of audience reception to his films, I'd estimate there's about a 40% chance of "Trap" receiving a CinemaScore of B or above.

Combining probabilities:
For this question to resolve as YES, we need either (a) OR (b) to occur. Using the formula for the probability of either event occurring:

P(A or B) = P(A) + P(B) - P(A and B)
= 0.70 + 0.40 - (0.70 * 0.40)
= 1.10 - 0.28
= 0.82

Therefore, the overall probability of this question resolving as YES is approximately 82%.

question.title: Will Trump's lead over Biden be greater than 2 and less than or equal to 3 on July 15, 2024, according to 538's national polling average?
question.body:
This question will resolve as Donald Trump's lead over Joe Biden in 538's [national polling average for the 2024 presidential election](https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/polls/president-general/2024/national/) as reported on the chart for the date of July 15, 2024, when accessed by Metaculus on July 17, 2024.

For the purposes of this question, a positive value means a Trump lead, while a negative value means Biden is leading. For example, as of July 5, 2024, the value reported for July 5 is Trump 2.4 points ahead of Biden, which would be a positive value of 2.4 for this purposes of this question.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current polling trends: As of July 5, 2024, Trump is leading Biden by 2.4 points according to the 538 national polling average. This is within the range we're looking for (between 2 and 3 points). 2. Time frame: We're forecasting for July 15, 2024, which is only 10 days from the last known data point. In such a short time, dramatic shifts are less likely unless there's a major event. 3. Historical volatility: Presidential polls tend to fluctuate, but usually within a relatively narrow range, especially this close to an election. 4. Potential events: We should consider any known upcoming events that could impact polling (debates, major policy announcements, etc.), but without specific information, we can't factor this in heavily. 5. Margin of error: Most polls have a margin of error of around 3 percentage points, which means small changes could easily push the lead in or out of our target range. 6. Regression to the mean: If the current lead is somewhat anomalous, we might expect it to regress slightly towards a longer-term average. Given that the current lead is already within our target range, and considering the short timeframe, it seems reasonably likely that Trump's lead will remain between 2 and 3 points. However, there's also a significant chance it could fall below 2 or rise above 3, given normal polling fluctuations and potential events. The question is quite specific, requiring the lead to be in a narrow 1-point range. This specificity reduces the probability compared to a broader range. Considering all these factors, I would estimate there's about a 30-40% chance that Trump's lead will be in this specific range on the given date.

question.title: Will Tucker Carlson be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Tucker Carlson is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. Any other candidate being selected will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently listed; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Tucker Carlson becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current status: Tucker Carlson is not a politician but a prominent conservative media personality. He has not declared any intention to run for president as of now. 2. Political experience: Carlson has no prior experience in elected office or government administration, which is typically seen as a prerequisite for presidential candidates. 3. Competition: There are already several high-profile Republicans who have announced their candidacy or are strongly considering running, including Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, Nikki Haley, and others. These candidates have significant political experience and established bases of support within the party. 4. Party dynamics: The Republican Party typically favors candidates with a track record in politics or government. While outsider candidates like Trump have succeeded, this is not the norm. 5. Media role: Carlson's position as a Fox News host gives him a platform to influence Republican voters, but it also complicates a potential run due to equal-time rules and potential conflicts of interest. 6. Time frame: The question resolution date is set for August 1, 2024, which is around the time when the Republican National Convention would typically occur. This leaves little time for Carlson to build a campaign infrastructure if he hasn't already started. 7. Historical precedent: While media personalities have run for president before (e.g., Pat Buchanan), they rarely secure major party nominations. 8. Public statements: Carlson has not expressed a strong interest in running for president, although he hasn't completely ruled it out either. Given these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Tucker Carlson would become the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While his media prominence gives him some advantages, the lack of political experience, absence of a declared candidacy, and strong competition from established political figures make it improbable that he would secure the nomination.

question.title: Will Biden drop out before July 20?
question.body: If Biden drops out or is otherwise unable to continue the race before July 20 midnight Eastern Time, this market will resolve to yes. Otherwise, this market will resolve to no.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Joe Biden dropping out before July 20, 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current status: As of now (2023), Joe Biden is the incumbent President of the United States and has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. 2. Age and health: Biden will be 81 years old at the time of the 2024 election, making him the oldest president in U.S. history. While his health has been generally good, his advanced age is a factor that could potentially impact his ability to continue the campaign. 3. Political landscape: Biden currently faces some challenges, including concerns about his age and mixed approval ratings. However, he remains the presumptive Democratic nominee, with no significant primary challengers emerging so far. 4. Historical precedent: It is extremely rare for an incumbent president to drop out of a re-election race. The last time this happened was in 1968 when Lyndon B. Johnson withdrew, but under very different circumstances. 5. Time frame: The question asks about dropping out before July 20, 2024, which is relatively close to the election. By this time, the Democratic primary process would be largely complete, making it even less likely for Biden to withdraw. 6. Party support: The Democratic Party leadership has generally rallied behind Biden's re-election bid, providing a strong base of support. 7. Unforeseen circumstances: While unlikely, there's always a possibility of unexpected health issues or major political scandals that could force a withdrawal. Considering these factors, it seems highly unlikely that Biden would drop out before July 20, 2024. While his age and potential health concerns introduce some uncertainty, the combination of his incumbent status, party support, and the late date in the election cycle make a withdrawal very improbable.

Apple, while a mature company, continues to innovate and has a loyal customer base. Its services segment is growing, which could provide additional value. 3. Market trends: The AI and machine learning markets are expected to continue growing, which could benefit Nvidia. However, there's also a risk of market saturation or competition catching up. Apple's market is more diverse, spanning smartphones, computers, wearables, and services, which provides some stability but might limit explosive growth. 4. Economic factors: Global economic conditions, interest rates, and potential recessions could impact both companies, but possibly in different ways. 5. Time frame: The question is set for about 10 months from now (as of September 2023). This is a relatively short period for such a significant market cap shift, given the current gap. 6. Historical precedent: It's rare for companies to overtake Apple in market cap, and when it has happened (e.g., Microsoft, Saudi Aramco), it's usually been temporary. Given these factors, while Nvidia has shown impressive growth, overtaking Apple in market cap by July 2024 seems unlikely. The gap is substantial, and Apple's diverse portfolio and strong market position provide resilience. However, Nvidia's potential in the AI market does leave some possibility for this outcome.

question.title: Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: This is a complex question that requires careful consideration of several factors: 1. Legal precedent: There have been attempts to use Section 3 of the 14th Amendment to disqualify candidates before, but they have rarely been successful. However, the January 6th events and Trump's alleged role in them have created a unique situation. 2. State-by-state variations: Different states may interpret and apply the 14th Amendment differently. Some states might be more inclined to take action against Trump than others. 3. Ongoing legal challenges: There are already efforts underway in some states to challenge Trump's eligibility under the 14th Amendment. For example, in September 2023, a lawsuit was filed in Colorado seeking to bar Trump from the ballot. 4. Time frame: The resolution date is July 15, 2024, which gives ample time for legal proceedings to unfold and for states to make decisions about their primary ballots. 5. Political climate: The issue is highly politicized, which could influence how aggressively some states pursue this avenue. 6. Supreme Court involvement: It's likely that any attempt to remove Trump from a ballot would be appealed and could potentially reach the Supreme Court, which might rule on the issue before the resolution date. 7. Trump's continued political activity: His actions and statements between now and the primaries could potentially strengthen or weaken arguments for his disqualification. Given these factors, I believe there is a significant chance that at least one state will attempt to remove or block Trump from their primary ballot under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. However, whether this attempt will be successful and withstand legal challenges by the resolution date is less certain. The fact that only one state needs to take this action for the question to resolve as 'Yes' increases the likelihood. However, the high-profile nature of such a decision and the likely legal challenges make it far from certain.

question.title: Will both of the following occur: (a) On July 17, 2024, will Nvidia's market capitalization be larger than Apple's? (b) Will Donald Trump be removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment?
question.body:
(a) This question resolves Yes if, on July 17, 2024, the market cap of Nvidia is greater than that of Apple, according to Companies Market Cap, when checked by Metaculus at approximately 4 PM EDT (8 PM UTC).

(b) This question will resolve as "Yes" if, *on* July 15, 2024:

Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment.

The removal or block is confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution.

The question will resolve as "No" if these conditions are not met as of July 15, 2024.

Note: The question does not account for legal battles, appeals, or subsequent reversals that might occur *after* the mentioned date. It strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: Let's break this down into two parts and analyze each separately: (a) Nvidia's market cap vs Apple's on July 17, 2024: As of September 2023, Apple's market cap is significantly larger than Nvidia's. However, Nvidia has been experiencing rapid growth due to the AI boom and its dominance in the GPU market. Still, for Nvidia to overtake Apple in less than a year would require an extraordinary shift in the market. Apple's market cap (as of September 2023): ~$2.7 trillion Nvidia's market cap (as of September 2023): ~$1.1 trillion While Nvidia has shown impressive growth, overtaking Apple would require either a massive surge in Nvidia's value or a significant drop in Apple's, or both. This seems unlikely in the given timeframe. (b) Donald Trump being removed or blocked from primary election ballots under Section 3 of the 14th Amendment: This is a complex legal and political issue. Several states have considered or are considering removing Trump from the ballot based on his actions related to the January 6th Capitol riot. Colorado and Maine have already taken steps to remove him, though these decisions are being challenged in court. The U.S. Supreme Court has agreed to hear arguments on this issue, with a decision expected in early 2024. Their ruling will likely set a precedent for all states. Given the current legal challenges and the Supreme Court's involvement, there's a significant chance that at least one state might keep Trump off the ballot by July 15, 2024. However, it's also possible that the Supreme Court could rule in Trump's favor, preventing any such removals. Combining these factors: For this question to resolve as YES, both conditions need to be met. While the second condition (Trump's ballot removal) has a reasonable chance of occurring, the first condition (Nvidia overtaking Apple) seems highly unlikely in the given timeframe. The combination of these two events makes the overall probability quite low.

question.title: Will either Nvidia's market cap exceed Apple's on July 17, 2024, or Donald Trump be removed from any U.S. state primary ballot for a federal office under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024?
question.body: This question resolves Yes if at least one of the following occurs: (a) On July 17, 2024, the market capitalization of Nvidia is greater than that of Apple, according to Companies Market Cap, when checked by Metaculus at approximately 4 PM EDT (8 PM UTC). (b) By July 15, 2024, Donald Trump has been officially removed or blocked from the primary election ballot of any U.S. state for a federal office (President, Senate, House of Representatives) under the grounds of Section 3 of the 14th Amendment. The removal or block must be confirmed through official state government announcements, court decisions, legal documentation, or credible media reports. Speculative reports, opinion pieces, or unofficial announcements will not suffice for resolution. The question strictly pertains to whether Donald Trump has been removed from any state's primary election ballot for a federal office under the specified grounds as of July 15, 2024. If Trump is removed or blocked from a ballot and then reinstated, such that as of July 15th he is not removed or blocked from any ballot, the question resolves negatively.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider both parts separately and then combine their probabilities. 1. Nvidia's market cap exceeding Apple's on July 17, 2024: As of September 2023, Apple's market cap is significantly larger than Nvidia's. While Nvidia has been growing rapidly due to the AI boom, it would need to continue this extraordinary growth for almost a year to surpass Apple. This is possible but not highly likely. The tech market is volatile, and many factors could affect both companies' valuations. I'd estimate this probability at around 20%. 2. Donald Trump being removed from any U.S. state primary ballot under the 14th Amendment by July 15, 2024: This is a complex legal and political issue. While there have been discussions about using the 14th Amendment to disqualify Trump, it's a controversial and unprecedented move. Some states might attempt this, but it would likely face immediate legal challenges. The Supreme Court would probably need to weigh in, and given its current composition, it might be hesitant to allow such a disqualification. However, the possibility cannot be completely ruled out. I'd estimate this probability at around 15%. To calculate the overall probability, we need to consider that only one of these events needs to occur for a 'Yes' resolution. The probability of at least one event occurring is the complement of the probability that neither event occurs: P(at least one) = 1 - P(neither) P(neither) = (1 - 0.20) * (1 - 0.15) = 0.80 * 0.85 = 0.68 Therefore, P(at least one) = 1 - 0.68 = 0.32

question.title: Will Francis Suarez be the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election?
question.body:
This question will resolve as **Yes** if Francis Suarez is selected by the Republican National Convention as the nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. All other candidates will resolve as **No**. This question is not restricted to the candidates currently mentioned; other options may be added in the future.

For this question, it is not relevant who receives the Republican nomination on the day of the 2024 US election; it is solely determined by who is selected by the delegates of the [Republican National Convention](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Republican_National_Convention).

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of Francis Suarez becoming the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election, we need to consider several factors: Current standing: Francis Suarez is the Mayor of Miami, Florida. While this is a notable position, it's not typically seen as a strong launching pad for a presidential nomination. Name recognition: Suarez is not widely known on the national stage compared to other potential Republican candidates like Donald Trump, Ron DeSantis, or Nikki Haley. Fundraising ability: As a relatively unknown candidate, Suarez may struggle to raise the substantial funds needed for a competitive national campaign. Political experience: Suarez lacks experience at the federal level, which is often seen as crucial for presidential candidates. Current polling: As of now, Suarez is not registering significant support in national polls for the Republican nomination. Competition: The Republican field is likely to be crowded with more established and well-known candidates, making it difficult for a lesser-known candidate to break through. Time until convention: While there is still time until the Republican National Convention in 2024, it would be challenging for Suarez to build the necessary momentum and support in this timeframe. Historical precedent: It's extremely rare for a mayor to directly become a major party's presidential nominee without holding higher office first. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that Francis Suarez will be selected as the Republican nominee for the 2024 US Presidential Election. While not impossible, it would require an extraordinary and unprecedented series of events for this to occur.

question.title: Will 538 Project Biden as the favorite on Friday?
question.body:
This market will resolve to “Yes” if Joe Biden has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Donald Trump according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. This market will resolve to “No” if Donald Trump has a higher probability of winning the US presidential election than Joe Biden according to the FiveThirtyEight election forecast for the day of July 19, 2024. If Biden and Trump have equal odds, this market will resolve 50-50.

The resolution source will be FiveThirtyEight's 2024 presidential election forecast, https://projects.fivethirtyeight.com/2024-election-forecast/, specifically the numbers indicated by the blue and red trend lines for this market's resolution date. Changes in the methodology by which FiveThirtyEight calculates its figures will have no bearing on the resolution of this market.

This market will resolve according to the datapoints for July 19 as soon as datapoints for July 20 become available. This market may not resolve until the July 20 datapoints are available. If no datapoints for July 19 are available by July 22, 11:59 PM ET, this market will resolve according to the nearest previous figures to July 19.

Please note the resolution refers to the odds of each candidate winning as a number out of 100 reported to the 1 digit mark (eg. "Trump 57 times out of 100"). The listed number of simulations out of 1,000 won by each candidate will NOT be considered.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current political landscape: As of now (June 2023), Joe Biden is the incumbent president and has announced his intention to run for re-election in 2024. Donald Trump, while not officially announced, is widely expected to be the Republican nominee. 2. Historical precedent: Incumbent presidents often have an advantage in re-election bids, but this is not always the case. 3. FiveThirtyEight's methodology: FiveThirtyEight is known for its data-driven approach and tends to be more conservative in its predictions compared to other forecasters. 4. Time until the forecast date: The forecast date (July 19, 2024) is more than a year away from now. A lot can change in the political landscape during this time. 5. Current polling: While early polls are not always indicative of the final result, they can provide some insight. Recent polls have shown a close race between Biden and Trump. 6. Economic factors: The state of the economy often plays a significant role in presidential elections. The economic situation in mid-2024 will likely influence the forecast. 7. Potential unforeseen events: Major national or international events could significantly impact the race. Given these factors, it's difficult to make a highly confident prediction. However, considering Biden's incumbent advantage and FiveThirtyEight's typically cautious approach, I believe there's a slightly higher chance that Biden will be favored in their forecast on July 19, 2024. That said, the race is likely to be close, and many factors could shift the prediction in either direction over the next year. The probability I assign to this outcome is not high, reflecting the significant uncertainty involved.

question.title: [Short Fuse] Will the proxy advisor Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) advise Tesla shareholders to vote against Elon Musk's $57 billion package OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk?
question.body: The question will resolve **Yes** if Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS) releases a statement explicitly advising Tesla shareholders to vote *against* Elon Musk's pay package at the 2024 Tesla shareholder meeting OR the re-election of Kimbal Musk to the Tesla board of directors. Otherwise the question will resolve as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving as YES, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical context: ISS has previously recommended against Elon Musk's compensation package and Kimbal Musk's re-election. In 2018, ISS advised shareholders to vote against Elon Musk's $2.6 billion compensation package. In 2022, ISS recommended voting against Kimbal Musk's re-election to the board. 2. Elon Musk's $57 billion package: This is an extraordinarily large compensation package, which is likely to draw scrutiny from proxy advisors like ISS. The size alone increases the likelihood of ISS recommending against it. 3. Corporate governance concerns: ISS typically focuses on good corporate governance practices. Tesla has faced criticism for its board composition, including the presence of Kimbal Musk (Elon's brother) as a board member, which could be seen as compromising independence. 4. Recent legal challenges: A Delaware judge recently ruled that Elon Musk's $56 billion Tesla pay package was unfair to shareholders and should be voided. This legal decision might influence ISS's recommendation. 5. ISS's role and reputation: As a leading proxy advisor, ISS is known for its independent stance and willingness to challenge executive compensation and board composition when they believe it's not in shareholders' best interests. 6. Time frame: The question resolution date is set for June 12, 2024, which gives ample time for ISS to review and make a recommendation before Tesla's 2024 shareholder meeting. Given these factors, it seems highly likely that ISS will recommend against either Elon Musk's pay package or Kimbal Musk's re-election, or possibly both. The recent court ruling on Musk's pay package and ISS's past recommendations make it particularly probable that they will advise against the compensation package. While there's always a possibility that circumstances could change or that Tesla could make adjustments to address concerns, based on the current information and historical precedent, the probability of ISS advising against at least one of these items appears quite high.

question.title: Will Biden be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August?
question.body:
Resolves YES if the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet (or other relevant body) invokes Section 4 of the 25th Amendment to formally declare that "the President is unable to discharge the powers and duties of his office" and cause the Vice President to serve as Acting President, before August 2024 (Eastern time).

The duration of the incapacity does not matter for this question.

Biden exiting the office of the Presidency by death, resignation, etc does not count. Biden invoking section 3 of the 25th amendment does not count.

Context: GOP lawmaker asks Merrick Garland to invoke 25th Amendment to remove Biden from office

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of President Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current health status: As of now, there are no publicly known severe health issues that would warrant such a drastic measure. Biden, while the oldest serving president, has maintained an active schedule and has not shown signs of severe incapacitation. 2. Political climate: The invocation of the 25th Amendment Section 4 is an extremely rare and serious action. It would require the Vice President and a majority of the Cabinet to agree on this course of action, which seems highly unlikely given the current political landscape and the loyalty of Biden's appointees. 3. Historical precedent: The 25th Amendment Section 4 has never been invoked in U.S. history, which underscores its extraordinary nature. 4. Recent context: The question mentions a GOP lawmaker asking Merrick Garland to invoke the 25th Amendment. However, such calls from opposition party members are often political rhetoric rather than based on genuine concerns about the President's capacity to serve. 5. Time frame: The resolution date is set for August 2, 2024, which is less than a month away from the current date. This short time frame further reduces the likelihood of such a significant political event occurring. 6. Checks and balances: Even if there were attempts to invoke the 25th Amendment, there are procedural safeguards in place that would make it difficult to implement quickly, especially if the President contests the declaration. 7. Public perception: There is no widespread public perception or media narrative suggesting that Biden is incapable of discharging his duties to the extent that would warrant invoking the 25th Amendment. Given these factors, it appears highly unlikely that President Biden will be declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4 before August 2024. While it's not impossible, it would require an extraordinary and sudden change in circumstances that is not currently foreseeable.

question.title: Will Joe Biden die before Saturday?
question.body:

Otherwise, resolves NO.

Short time frame: The question asks about a specific, short period (about 3 weeks from the creation date to the resolution date). Historical precedent: No sitting U.S. president has died in office since John F. Kennedy in 1963, and natural deaths of presidents in office are even rarer. Given these factors, the probability of Joe Biden dying before Saturday, July 27, 2024, is very low. While it's impossible to predict with absolute certainty, and unexpected events can always occur, the combination of his current health status, the short timeframe, and the excellent care he receives as president all contribute to a very low probability of this event occurring.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this event, we need to consider the likelihood of both conditions occurring independently and then together. While Biden is the oldest president in U.S. history, which might increase concerns about his capacity, there have been no serious indications of incapacitation. His administration and party have consistently supported his ability to serve. The likelihood of this happening is very low. While advanced age does increase mortality risk, Biden has access to excellent healthcare and regular medical check-ups. There have been no public indications of severe health issues that would suggest imminent death. The probability of any 81-year-old man dying within a specific one-year period is relatively low, and even lower for someone with Biden's level of care. The combination of these two already unlikely events happening in this specific sequence and timeframe makes the overall probability extremely low.

(b) Joe Biden dies: Resolves YES if there is an official announcement of Joe Biden's death before market close at the end of Friday, July 26th, 2024. Otherwise, resolves NO.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of this question resolving YES, we need to consider both scenarios separately and then combine their likelihoods. (a) Biden being declared incapacitated under the 25th Amendment Section 4: This is an extremely rare event that has never been invoked in U.S. history. For this to occur, there would need to be a severe decline in Biden's cognitive or physical health, to the point where he is unable to discharge his duties, and the Vice President and Cabinet would need to agree on this assessment. While there have been concerns about Biden's age and occasional gaffes, there is no concrete evidence of severe incapacitation. The administration and Democratic Party would likely resist such a move unless absolutely necessary, as it would be politically damaging. The probability of this occurring in the next year is very low. (b) Joe Biden dies before August 2024: Biden is currently 80 years old (born November 20, 1942). While his age does increase the risk of mortality, he has access to excellent healthcare and appears to be in relatively good health for his age. According to actuarial tables, the annual mortality rate for an 80-year-old male in the U.S. is approximately 5.6%. However, this is for the average population, and Biden likely has better odds due to his access to top-tier medical care. The probability of scenario (b) is higher but still relatively low, perhaps around 4-5% for the given timeframe. However, they are not simply additive as there is a small chance of overlap (i.e., Biden could be declared incapacitated and then die). Taking all of this into account, I would estimate the total probability to be slightly higher than the mortality risk alone, but not by much due to the very low likelihood of scenario (a).

question.title: Will the Pandemic Agreement be approved at the May 2024 World Health Assembly?
question.body: This question will resolve as **Yes** if, during the May 2024 World Health Assembly (WHA) the Pandemic Agreement is approved in a vote, according to reports from credible sources.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the Pandemic Agreement being approved at the May 2024 World Health Assembly, we need to consider several factors: 1. Timeline: The question is asking about an event that is about a year away from the creation date. This gives member states time to negotiate and refine the agreement, but also leaves room for potential obstacles. 2. Global health context: The COVID-19 pandemic has highlighted the need for better international cooperation in handling global health crises. This could increase motivation to approve such an agreement. 3. Previous efforts: The World Health Organization (WHO) has been working on this agreement since December 2021, showing a sustained effort and commitment to its development. 4. Political climate: While there's generally broad support for improving pandemic preparedness, some countries may have reservations about potential sovereignty issues or economic impacts. 5. Complexity of negotiations: International agreements often involve complex negotiations and compromises, which could delay the approval process. 6. WHO's track record: The WHO has successfully implemented other international health regulations in the past, which suggests some capability in achieving consensus. 7. Urgency: The recent pandemic experience may create a sense of urgency to approve measures that could help prevent or mitigate future health crises. 8. Potential opposition: Some countries or interest groups might oppose certain aspects of the agreement, which could lead to delays or modifications. Given these factors, I believe there's a moderate to good chance of the Pandemic Agreement being approved at the May 2024 WHA. The extended timeline for negotiation, the global recognition of the need for better pandemic preparedness, and the WHO's experience in implementing international health measures all work in favor of approval. However, the complexity of international negotiations and potential opposition from some parties introduce uncertainty.

question.title: Will OpenAI publicly commit to the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle before July 1, 2024?
question.body:
This question resolves as **Yes** if, before July 1, 2024, both of the following are true:

- OpenAI publicly commits to the "no retaliation for public risk disclosure" principle via a statement from the company or a company spokesperson, such as Sam Altman. The statement may be formal (such as a press release) or informal (such as a tweet or quote in an interview). The statement from OpenAI must indicate a new level of commitment to the principle in question, relative to the time the righttowarn.ai statement was published; it cannot be a reiteration that, for example, "we already have a culture of open criticism". 
- Metaculus verifies that the company has accepted the principle to the satisfaction of at least one member of righttowarn.ai. Metaculus may reach out to select signatories or endorsers to assess their level of satisfaction with OpenAI's commitment. Statements must be at least as rigorous as "this was a good first step" for this question to resolve as **Yes**.

Given these factors, I believe there's a moderate chance of this occurring. The long time frame and increasing focus on AI ethics work in favor of it happening. The main obstacles are likely to be OpenAI's potential reluctance to make such a specific commitment and the need for verification from external parties. question.title: Will the United States win gold in both Men's and Women's 5v5 basketball at the Paris Olympics
question.body: Resolves Yes if Team USA wins both gold medals. Resolves no if either the men's or women's team places anywhere other than gold.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of the United States winning gold in both Men's and Women's 5v5 basketball at the Paris Olympics, we need to consider several factors: 1. Historical performance: The U.S. has been dominant in Olympic basketball for both men and women. The men's team has won gold in four of the last five Olympics (2008, 2012, 2016, 2021), while the women's team has been even more dominant, winning gold in every Olympics since 1996 (seven consecutive golds). 2. Talent pool: The U.S. has the deepest talent pool in basketball for both men and women, with the NBA and WNBA being the premier professional leagues globally. 3. Recent performances: The U.S. men's team won gold in Tokyo 2021, while the women's team also secured gold, continuing their streak. 4. Competition: While other nations have improved in basketball, the U.S. still remains the favorite in both categories. However, teams like Spain, Australia, and Serbia for men, and Australia, Spain, and Japan for women have shown they can compete at a high level. 5. Preparation: The U.S. teams typically have less time to prepare together compared to other national teams, which can sometimes lead to early tournament struggles. 6. Pressure and expectations: The immense pressure to win gold can sometimes affect performance, as seen in the men's team's bronze medal finish in 2004. 7. Potential roster changes: The exact roster for 2024 is not yet known, which adds some uncertainty. 8. Single elimination format: In the knockout stages, a single bad game can lead to elimination, adding an element of unpredictability. Given these factors, the U.S. is still the favorite to win both gold medals. The women's team seems more likely to secure gold given their consistent dominance. The men's team, while still favored, faces stiffer competition and has shown more vulnerability in recent years. Considering all these aspects, I would estimate a high probability of success, but not a certainty.

question.title: Will the Philadelphia 76ers win the 2024 NBA Finals?
question.body:
The question resolves **Yes** if the Philadelphia 76ers are crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to [the NBA](https://www.nba.com/). 

It resolves **No** for all other teams as they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the Philadelphia 76ers' chances of winning the 2024 NBA Finals, we need to consider several factors: 1. Current team strength: The 76ers have a strong core led by Joel Embiid, who was the 2023 NBA MVP. They also have talented players like Tyrese Maxey and Tobias Harris. 2. James Harden situation: As of October 2023, there's uncertainty surrounding James Harden's future with the team, which could impact their performance. 3. Eastern Conference competition: The 76ers face tough competition in the East from teams like the Milwaukee Bucks, Boston Celtics, and Miami Heat. 4. Western Conference threats: Strong teams like the Denver Nuggets (defending champions), Phoenix Suns, and Golden State Warriors pose significant challenges. 5. Recent playoff performance: The 76ers have consistently made the playoffs but have struggled to advance past the second round in recent years. 6. Coaching: Doc Rivers is an experienced coach, but there have been questions about his ability to lead teams to championships. 7. Time until the Finals: With the Finals occurring in June 2024, there's time for roster changes, injuries, and other factors to influence the team's chances. 8. Historical context: The 76ers haven't won an NBA championship since 1983, indicating a long-standing difficulty in reaching this goal. Given these factors, the 76ers are a competitive team with a chance to contend, but they are not the favorites to win the 2024 NBA Finals. They have significant hurdles to overcome, both within their conference and potentially in the Finals against Western Conference powerhouses. While they have a superstar in Embiid and a solid supporting cast, the uncertainty around Harden and their recent playoff struggles make it difficult to predict them as champions. They likely have a better chance than many teams, but still less than a 20% probability of winning it all.

question.body:

(b) Resolves Yes if the Philadelphia 76ers are crowned the champion of the 2024 NBA Finals, according to the NBA. Resolves No for all other teams as they are eliminated from contention.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To answer this question, we need to consider the likelihood of two separate events and then combine them, as the question resolves YES if either of these events occurs. (a) Team USA winning both Men's and Women's 5v5 basketball gold medals at the Paris Olympics: Team USA has a strong history in Olympic basketball. The women's team has been particularly dominant, winning the last seven consecutive Olympic gold medals (1996-2021). The men's team has won four consecutive gold medals (2008-2021), with their last non-gold finish being bronze in 2004. Given this track record, the women's team has a very high probability of winning gold, perhaps around 90%. The men's team, while still favored, faces stiffer competition from other nations that have been improving in recent years. Their chances might be around 70-75%. The probability of both teams winning gold would be the product of their individual probabilities. Let's estimate this at approximately 0.90 * 0.75 = 0.675 or 67.5%. (b) The Philadelphia 76ers winning the 2024 NBA Finals: The 76ers are a strong team with stars like Joel Embiid, but they are not considered the top favorite for the 2024 NBA championship. There are several other strong contenders like the Boston Celtics, Milwaukee Bucks, Denver Nuggets, and Phoenix Suns. Additionally, there's uncertainty surrounding James Harden's situation with the team. Given the competitive nature of the NBA and the 76ers' recent playoff performances (they haven't made it past the second round since 2001), their chances of winning the 2024 NBA Finals are relatively low. Let's estimate their probability at around 8-10%. Combining the probabilities: The question resolves YES if either (a) or (b) occurs. To calculate this, we need to find the probability that at least one of these events happens. This is equal to 1 minus the probability that neither event happens. P(at least one event) = 1 - P(neither event) = 1 - [(1 - P(a)) * (1 - P(b))] = 1 - [(1 - 0.675) * (1 - 0.09)] ≈ 1 - (0.325 * 0.91) ≈ 1 - 0.29575 ≈ 0.70425.

question.title: Will Democrats have a brokered convention in 2024?
question.body: This question resolves as **Yes** if the Democratic Party requires more than one round of voting in its roll call ballot to formally nominate its candidate for the 2024 US presidential election. If only one ballot is required, then this question resolves as **No**.

metadata.chain_of_thought: To assess the probability of a brokered convention for the Democrats in 2024, we need to consider several factors: 1. Incumbent advantage: Joe Biden is the incumbent president and the presumptive nominee for the Democratic Party. Historically, incumbent presidents rarely face significant challenges within their own party. 2. Current political landscape: As of the question's creation date (July 8, 2024), there have been no major challengers to Biden's nomination that have gained significant traction. 3. Party unity: The Democratic Party has generally shown unity behind Biden, with most prominent party members supporting his re-election bid. 4. Timing: The question was created very close to the convention date (less than a month before the resolution date). If there were serious challenges to Biden's nomination, they would likely have emerged and gained momentum well before this point. 5. Historical precedent: Brokered conventions are extremely rare in modern American politics. The last time Democrats had a brokered convention was in 1952. 6. Delegate allocation: The Democratic Party's proportional allocation of delegates makes it more likely for a clear winner to emerge before the convention. 7. Party rules: The Democratic National Committee has rules in place to prevent prolonged nomination battles, including the role of superdelegates if no candidate secures a majority on the first ballot. Given these factors, it is highly unlikely that the Democrats will have a brokered convention in 2024. The only scenario where this might occur would be if there was a sudden, major event that dramatically changed the political landscape (e.g., a severe health issue for Biden). However, even in such a case, the party would likely rally around a replacement candidate quickly to avoid a contentious convention.
